projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts uses TEI Simple to encode the Shakespeare texts edited by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptions and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweler, and Merchant, at several doors.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Good day, sir.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: I am glad you’re well.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: I have not seen you long. How goes the world?

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: It wears, sir, as it grows.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Ay, that’s well known.
But what particular rarity, what strange,
Which manifold record not matches? See,
Magic of bounty, all these spirits thy power
Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: I know them both. Th’ other’s a jeweler.

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.l: O, ’tis a worthy lord!

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.l: Nay, that’s most fixed.

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.l: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,
To an untirable and continuate goodness.
He passes.

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.l: I have a jewel here—

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.l: O, pray, let’s see ’t. For the Lord Timon, sir?

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.l: If he will touch the estimate. But for that—

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: When we for recompense have praised the vile,
It stains the glory in that happy verse
Which aptly sings the good.

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.l: ’Tis a good form.

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.l: And rich. Here is a water, look ye.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication
To the great lord.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: A thing slipped idly from me.
Our poesy is as a gum which oozes
From whence ’tis nourished. The fire i’ th’ flint
Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame
Provokes itself and, like the current, flies
Each bound it chases. What have you there?

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.
Let’s see your piece.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: ’Tis a good piece.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: So ’tis. This comes off well and excellent.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: Indifferent.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Admirable! How this grace
Speaks his own standing! What a mental power
This eye shoots forth! How big imagination
Moves in this lip! To th’ dumbness of the gesture
One might interpret.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: It is a pretty mocking of the life.
Here is a touch. Is ’t good?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: I will say of it,
It tutors nature. Artificial strife
Lives in these touches livelier than life.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: How this lord is followed.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: The senators of Athens, happy men.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: Look, more.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: You see this confluence, this great flood of visitors.
( Indicating his poem.) I have in this rough work shaped out a man
Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug
With amplest entertainment. My free drift
Halts not particularly but moves itself
In a wide sea of wax. No leveled malice
Infects one comma in the course I hold,
But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,
Leaving no tract behind.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: How shall I understand you?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: I will unbolt to you.
You see how all conditions, how all minds,
As well of glib and slipp’ry creatures as
Of grave and austere quality, tender down
Their services to Lord Timon. His large fortune,
Upon his good and gracious nature hanging,
Subdues and properties to his love and tendance
All sorts of hearts— yea, from the glass-faced flatterer
To Apemantus, that few things loves better
Than to abhor himself; even he drops down
The knee before him and returns in peace
Most rich in Timon’s nod.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: I saw them speak together.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill
Feigned Fortune to be throned. The base o’ th’ mount
Is ranked with all deserts, all kind of natures
That labor on the bosom of this sphere
To propagate their states. Amongst them all
Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fixed,
One do I personate of Lord Timon’s frame,
Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her,
Whose present grace to present slaves and servants
Translates his rivals.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: ’Tis conceived to scope.
This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,
With one man beckoned from the rest below,
Bowing his head against the steepy mount
To climb his happiness, would be well expressed
In our condition.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Nay, sir, but hear me on.
All those which were his fellows but of late,
Some better than his value, on the moment
Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,
Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,
Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him
Drink the free air.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: Ay, marry, what of these?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood
Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants,
Which labored after him to the mountain’s top
Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,
Not one accompanying his declining foot.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: ’Tis common.
A thousand moral paintings I can show
That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune’s
More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well
To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen
The foot above the head.

div.stage: Trumpets sound. Enter Lord Timon, addressing himself courteously to every suitor. He is accompanied by a Messenger and followed by Lucilius and other Servants.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Imprisoned is he, say you?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Ay, my good lord. Five talents is his debt,
His means most short, his creditors most strait.
Your honorable letter he desires
To those have shut him up, which failing
Periods his comfort.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Noble Ventidius. Well,
I am not of that feather to shake off
My friend when he must need me. I do know him
A gentleman that well deserves a help,
Which he shall have. I’ll pay the debt and free him.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Your Lordship ever binds him.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Commend me to him. I will send his ransom;
And, being enfranchised, bid him come to me.
’Tis not enough to help the feeble up,
But to support him after. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: All happiness to your Honor.

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Freely, good father.

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I have so. What of him?

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Attends he here or no?— Lucilius!

sp.speaker: LUCILIUS
sp.l: Here, at your Lordship’s service.

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,
By night frequents my house. I am a man
That from my first have been inclined to thrift,
And my estate deserves an heir more raised
Than one which holds a trencher.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Well. What further?

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: One only daughter have I, no kin else
On whom I may confer what I have got.
The maid is fair, o’ th’ youngest for a bride,
And I have bred her at my dearest cost
In qualities of the best. This man of thine
Attempts her love. I prithee, noble lord,
Join with me to forbid him her resort.
Myself have spoke in vain.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: The man is honest.

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: Therefore he will be, Timon.
His honesty rewards him in itself;
It must not bear my daughter.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Does she love him?

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: She is young and apt.
Our own precedent passions do instruct us
What levity’s in youth.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Love you the maid?

sp.speaker: LUCILIUS
sp.l: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: If in her marriage my consent be missing—
I call the gods to witness— I will choose
Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world
And dispossess her all.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: How shall she be endowed
If she be mated with an equal husband?

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: This gentleman of mine hath served me long.
To build his fortune, I will strain a little,
For ’tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter.
What you bestow, in him I’ll counterpoise,
And make him weigh with her.

sp.speaker: OLD MAN
sp.l: Most noble lord,
Pawn me to this your honor, she is his.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: My hand to thee; mine honor on my promise.

sp.speaker: LUCILIUS
sp.l: Humbly I thank your Lordship. Never may
That state or fortune fall into my keeping
Which is not owed to you.

div.stage: He exits with the old Athenian.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.l: Vouchsafe my labor, and long live your Lordship.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I thank you. You shall hear from me anon.
Go not away.— What have you there, my friend?

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: A piece of painting which I do beseech
Your Lordship to accept.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Painting is welcome.
The painting is almost the natural man,
For, since dishonor traffics with man’s nature,
He is but outside; these penciled figures are
Even such as they give out. I like your work,
And you shall find I like it. Wait attendance
Till you hear further from me.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.l: The gods preserve you.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Well fare you, gentleman. Give me your hand.
We must needs dine together.— Sir, your jewel
Hath suffered under praise.

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.l: What, my lord? Dispraise?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: A mere satiety of commendations.
If I should pay you for ’t as ’tis extolled,
It would unclew me quite.

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.l: My lord, ’tis rated
As those which sell would give. But you well know
Things of like value, differing in the owners,
Are prizèd by their masters. Believe ’t, dear lord,
You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Well mocked.

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.l: No, my good lord. He speaks the common tongue,
Which all men speak with him.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Look who comes here. Will you be chid?

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.p: We’ll bear, with your Lordship.

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.p: He’ll spare none.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow—
When thou art Timon’s dog, and these knaves honest.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Why dost thou call them knaves? Thou know’st them not.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Are they not Athenians?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Then I repent not.

sp.speaker: JEWELER
sp.p: You know me, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Thou know’st I do. I called thee by thy
name.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Of nothing so much as that I am not like
Timon.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Whither art going?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: To knock out an honest Athenian’s brains.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: That’s a deed thou ’lt die for.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Right, if doing nothing be death by th’ law.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: How lik’st thou this picture, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: The best, for the innocence.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Wrought he not well that painted it?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
He wrought better that made the painter,
and yet he’s but a filthy piece of work.

sp.speaker: PAINTER
sp.p: You’re a dog.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Thy mother’s of my generation. What’s
she, if I be a dog?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: No. I eat not lords.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: An thou shouldst, thou ’dst anger ladies.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
O, they eat lords. So they come by great
bellies.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: That’s a lascivious apprehension.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
So thou apprehend’st it. Take it for thy
labor.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Not so well as plain-dealing, which will
not cost a man a doit.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: What dost thou think ’tis worth?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Not worth my thinking.— How now, poet?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: How now, philosopher?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Art not one?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Then I lie not.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Art not a poet?

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Then thou liest. Look in thy last work,
where thou hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

sp.speaker: POET
sp.p: That’s not feigned. He is so.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee
for thy labor. He that loves to be flattered is worthy
o’ th’ flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
E’en as Apemantus does now— hate a lord
with my heart.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: What? Thyself?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
That I had no angry wit to be a lord.— Art
not thou a merchant?

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.p: Ay, Apemantus.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not.

sp.speaker: MERCHANT
sp.p: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Traffic’s thy god, and thy god confound
thee!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: What trumpet’s that?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: ’Tis Alcibiades and some twenty horse,
All of companionship.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Pray, entertain them. Give them guide to us.
You must needs dine with me. Go not you hence
Till I have thanked you.— When dinner’s done
Show me this piece.— I am joyful of your sights.
Most welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: So, so, there!
Aches contract and starve your supple joints!
That there should be small love amongst these sweet knaves,
And all this courtesy! The strain of man’s bred out
Into baboon and monkey.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed
Most hungerly on your sight.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Right welcome, sir.
Ere we depart, we’ll share a bounteous time
In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: What time o’ day is ’t, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Time to be honest.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: That time serves still.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: The most accursèd thou, that still omit’st it.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Thou art going to Lord Timon’s feast?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Ay, to see meat fill knaves, and wine heat fools.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Why, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to give thee none.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: Hang thyself.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding.
Make thy requests to thy friend.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I’ll spurn thee hence.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o’ th’ ass.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: He’s opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in
And taste Lord Timon’s bounty? He outgoes
The very heart of kindness.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: He pours it out. Plutus, the god of gold,
Is but his steward. No meed but he repays
Sevenfold above itself. No gift to him
But breeds the giver a return exceeding
All use of quittance.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: The noblest mind he carries
That ever governed man.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Long may he live in fortunes. Shall we in?
I’ll keep you company.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet served in, and then enter Lord Timon, the States, the Athenian Lords ( including Lucius), Alcibiades, and Ventidius( which Timon redeemed from prison). Flavius and others are in attendance. Then comes dropping after all Apemantus discontentedly like himself.

sp.speaker: VENTIDIUS
sp.l: Most honored Timon,
It hath pleased the gods to remember my father’s age
And call him to long peace.
He is gone happy and has left me rich.
Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound
To your free heart, I do return those talents,
Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help
I derived liberty.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: O, by no means,
Honest Ventidius. You mistake my love.
I gave it freely ever, and there’s none
Can truly say he gives if he receives.
If our betters play at that game, we must not dare
To imitate them. Faults that are rich are fair.

sp.speaker: VENTIDIUS
sp.l: A noble spirit!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Nay, my lords, ceremony was but devised at first
To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,
Recanting goodness, sorry ere ’tis shown;
But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Pray, sit. More welcome are you to my fortunes
Than my fortunes to me.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: My lord, we always have confessed it.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Ho, ho, “ confessed it”? Hanged it, have you not?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: O Apemantus, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: No, you shall not make me welcome.
I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Fie, thou ’rt a churl. You’ve got a humor there
Does not become a man. ’Tis much to blame.—
sp.p:
They say, my lords, Ira furor brevis est, but yond
man is ever angry. Go, let him have a table by
himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is
he fit for ’t indeed.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon. I
come to observe; I give thee warning on ’t.

sp.speaker: TIMON
APEMANTUS
sp.p:
I scorn thy meat. ’Twould choke me, for I
should ne’er flatter thee. ( Apart.) O you gods,
what a number of men eats Timon, and he sees ’em
not! It grieves me to see so many dip their meat in
one man’s blood; and all the madness is, he cheers
them up too.
sp.l: I wonder men dare trust themselves with men.
Methinks they should invite them without knives.
Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.
sp.p:
There’s much example for ’t. The fellow that sits
next him, now parts bread with him, pledges the
breath of him in a divided draft, is the readiest
man to kill him. ’T ’as been proved. If I were a huge
man, I should fear to drink at meals,
sp.l: Lest they should spy my wind-pipe’s dangerous notes.
Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: My lord, in heart! And let the health go round.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
“ Flow this way”? A brave fellow.
He keeps his tides well. Those healths will make
thee and thy state look ill, Timon.
sp.l: Here’s that which is too weak to be a sinner,
Honest water, which ne’er left man i’ th’ mire.
This and my food are equals. There’s no odds.
Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.

lg.head: Apemantus’ grace.
lg.l: Immortal gods, I crave no pelf.
I pray for no man but myself.
Grant I may never prove so fond
To trust man on his oath or bond,
Or a harlot for her weeping,
Or a dog that seems a-sleeping,
Or a keeper with my freedom,
Or my friends if I should need ’em.
Rich men sin, and I eat root.

sp.l: Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Captain Alcibiades, your heart’s in the field now.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.p: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies
than a dinner of friends.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.p:
So they were bleeding new, my lord,
there’s no meat like ’em. I could wish my best
friend at such a feast.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Would all those flatterers were
thine enemies, then, that then thou mightst kill
’em and bid me to ’em.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.p:
Might we but have that happiness, my
lord, that you would once use our hearts, whereby
we might express some part of our zeals, we
should think ourselves forever perfect.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods
themselves have provided that I shall have much
help from you. How had you been my friends else?
Why have you that charitable title from thousands,
did not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told
more of you to myself than you can with modesty
speak in your own behalf. And thus far I confirm
you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any
friends if we should ne’er have need of ’em? They
were the most needless creatures living, should we
ne’er have use for ’em, and would most resemble
sweet instruments hung up in cases, that keeps
their sounds to themselves. Why, I have often
wished myself poorer that I might come nearer to
you. We are born to do benefits. And what better or
properer can we call our own than the riches of
our friends? O, what a precious comfort ’tis to
have so many, like brothers, commanding one
another’s fortunes. O, joy’s e’en made away ere ’t
can be born! Mine eyes cannot hold out water,
methinks. To forget their faults, I drink to you.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Thou weep’st to make them drink,
Timon.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Joy had the like conception in our eyes
And, at that instant, like a babe sprung up.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

sp.speaker: THIRD LORD
sp.l: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Much!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: What means that trump?
How now?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p:
Please you, my lord, there are certain ladies
most desirous of admittance.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Ladies? What are their wills?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p:
There comes with them a forerunner, my lord,
which bears that office to signify their pleasures.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: I pray, let them be admitted.

sp.speaker: CUPID
sp.l: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all
That of his bounties taste! The five best senses
Acknowledge thee their patron, and come freely
To gratulate thy plenteous bosom. There
Taste, touch, all, pleased from thy table rise;
They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: They’re welcome all. Let ’em have kind admittance.
Music, make their welcome!

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.l: You see, my lord, how ample you’re beloved.

div.stage: Music. Enter the masque of Ladies as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: Hoy-day!
What a sweep of vanity comes this way.
They dance? They are madwomen.
Like madness is the glory of this life
As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.
We make ourselves fools to disport ourselves
And spend our flatteries to drink those men
Upon whose age we void it up again
With poisonous spite and envy.
Who lives that’s not depravèd or depraves?
Who dies that bears not one spurn to their graves
Of their friends’ gift?
I should fear those that dance before me now
Would one day stamp upon me. ’T ’as been done.
Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

div.stage: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of Timon, and to show their loves each single out an Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,
Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,
Which was not half so beautiful and kind.
You have added worth unto ’t and luster,
And entertained me with mine own device.
I am to thank you for ’t.

sp.speaker: FIRST LADY
sp.l: My lord, you take us even at the best.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Faith, for the worst is filthy and
would not hold taking, I doubt me.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you.
Please you to dispose yourselves.

sp.speaker: ALL LADIES
sp.l: Most thankfully, my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Flavius.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: The little casket bring me hither.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Yes, my lord. ( Aside.) More jewels yet?
There is no crossing him in ’s humor;
Else I should tell him well, i’ faith I should.
When all’s spent, he’d be crossed then, an he could.
’Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind,
That man might ne’er be wretched for his mind.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: Where be our men?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: Here, my lord, in readiness.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: Our horses.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: O my friends, I have one word
To say to you. Look you, my good lord,
I must entreat you, honor me so much
As to advance this jewel. Accept it and wear it,
Kind my lord.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: I am so far already in your gifts—

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: So are we all.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: My lord, there are certain nobles of the Senate
Newly alighted and come to visit you.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: They are fairly welcome.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: I beseech your Honor,
Vouchsafe me a word. It does concern you near.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Near? Why, then, another time I’ll hear thee.
I prithee, let’s be provided to show them entertainment.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: I scarce know how.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT
sp.l: May it please your Honor, Lord Lucius,
Out of his free love, hath presented to you
Four milk-white horses trapped in silver.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I shall accept them fairly. Let the presents
Be worthily entertained.
How now? What news?

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVANT
sp.p:
Please you, my lord, that honorable
gentleman Lord Lucullus entreats your company
tomorrow to hunt with him and has sent your
Honor two brace of greyhounds.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I’ll hunt with him; and let them be received,
Not without fair reward.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: What will this come to?
He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,
And all out of an empty coffer.
Nor will he know his purse or yield me this—
To show him what a beggar his heart is,
Being of no power to make his wishes good.
His promises fly so beyond his state
That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes
For ev’ry word. He is so kind that he
Now pays interest for ’t. His land’s put to their books.
Well, would I were gently put out of office
Before I were forced out.
Happier is he that has no friend to feed
Than such that do e’en enemies exceed.
I bleed inwardly for my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: You do yourselves much wrong.
You bate too much of your own merits.
( Offering a gift.) Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

sp.speaker: THIRD LORD
sp.l: O, he’s the very soul of bounty!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
And now I remember, my lord, you gave good
words the other day of a bay courser I rode on. ’Tis
yours because you liked it.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: You may take my word, my lord. I know no man
Can justly praise but what he does affect.
I weigh my friends’ affection with mine own.
I’ll tell you true, I’ll call to you.

sp.speaker: ALL LORDS
sp.l: O, none so welcome.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I take all and your several visitations
So kind to heart, ’tis not enough to give.
Methinks I could deal kingdoms to my friends
And ne’er be weary.— Alcibiades,
Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich.
It comes in charity to thee, for all thy living
Is ’mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast
Lie in a pitched field.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: We are so virtuously bound—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: And so am I to you.

sp.speaker: SECOND LORD
sp.l: So infinitely endeared—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: All to you.— Lights, more lights.

sp.speaker: FIRST LORD
sp.l: The best of happiness, honor, and fortunes
Keep with you, Lord Timon.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Ready for his friends.

div.stage: All but Timon and Apemantus exit.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.l: What a coil’s here,
Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!
I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums
That are given for ’em. Friendship’s full of dregs.
Methinks false hearts should never have sound legs.
Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court’sies.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen,
I would be good to thee.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
No, I’ll nothing, for if I should be bribed
too, there would be none left to rail upon thee, and
then thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou giv’st so
long, Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself
in paper shortly. What needs these feasts, pomps,
and vainglories?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I am
sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell, and
come with better music.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
So. Thou wilt not hear me now, thou shalt
not then. I’ll lock thy heaven from thee.
sp.l: O, that men’s ears should be
To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

sp.speaker: SENATOR
sp.l: And late five thousand. To Varro and to Isidore
He owes nine thousand, besides my former sum,
Which makes it five-and-twenty. Still in motion
Of raging waste! It cannot hold; it will not.
If I want gold, steal but a beggar’s dog
And give it Timon, why, the dog coins gold.
If I would sell my horse and buy twenty more
Better than he, why, give my horse to Timon—
Ask nothing; give it him— it foals me straight,
And able horses. No porter at his gate
But rather one that smiles and still invites
All that pass by. It cannot hold. No reason
Can sound his state in safety.— Caphis, ho!
Caphis, I say!

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: Here, sir. What is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: SENATOR
sp.l: Get on your cloak and haste you to Lord Timon.
Importune him for my moneys. Be not ceased
With slight denial, nor then silenced when
“ Commend me to your master” and the cap
Plays in the right hand thus; but tell him
My uses cry to me. I must serve my turn
Out of mine own. His days and times are past,
And my reliances on his fracted dates
Have smit my credit. I love and honor him
But must not break my back to heal his finger.
Immediate are my needs, and my relief
Must not be tossed and turned to me in words
But find supply immediate. Get you gone.
Put on a most importunate aspect,
A visage of demand, for I do fear
When every feather sticks in his own wing
Lord Timon will be left a naked gull,
Which flashes now a phoenix. Get you gone.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: I go, sir.

sp.speaker: SENATOR
sp.l: “ I go, sir”? Take the bonds along with you
And have the dates in. Come.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: SENATOR
sp.l: Go.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Steward Flavius, with many bills in his hand.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: No care, no stop, so senseless of expense
That he will neither know how to maintain it
Nor cease his flow of riot. Takes no account
How things go from him nor resumes no care
Of what is to continue. Never mind
Was to be so unwise to be so kind.
What shall be done? He will not hear till feel.
I must be round with him, now he comes from hunting.
Fie, fie, fie, fie!

div.stage: Enter Caphis, and the Men of Isidore and Varro.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: Good even, Varro. What, you come for money?

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: Is ’t not your business too?

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.p: It is. And yours too, Isidore?

sp.speaker: ISIDORE’S MAN
sp.p: It is so.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.p: Would we were all discharged!

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: I fear it.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.p: Here comes the lord.

div.stage: Enter Timon, and his train, with Alcibiades.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: So soon as dinner’s done we’ll forth again,
My Alcibiades. ( To Caphis.) With me? What is your will?

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: My lord, here is a note of certain dues.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Dues? Whence are you?

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: Of Athens here, my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Go to my steward.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: Please it your Lordship, he hath put me off
To the succession of new days this month.
My master is awaked by great occasion
To call upon his own and humbly prays you
That with your other noble parts you’ll suit
In giving him his right.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Mine honest friend,
I prithee but repair to me next morning.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: Nay, good my lord—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Contain thyself, good friend.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.l: One Varro’s servant,
my good lord—

sp.speaker: ISIDORE’S MAN
sp.l: From Isidore. He humbly prays your speedy payment.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.l: If you did know, my lord, my master’s wants—

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.l: ’Twas due on forfeiture, my lord, six weeks and past.

sp.speaker: ISIDORE’S MAN
sp.l: Your steward puts me off, my lord, and I
Am sent expressly to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Give me breath.—
I do beseech you, good my lords, keep on.
I’ll wait upon you instantly.
Come hither. Pray you,
How goes the world that I am thus encountered
With clamorous demands of debt, broken bonds,
And the detention of long-since-due debts
Against my honor?

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Please you, gentlemen,
The time is unagreeable to this business.
Your importunacy cease till after dinner,
That I may make his Lordship understand
Wherefore you are not paid.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Do so, my friends.—
See them well entertained.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Pray, draw near.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.p:
Stay, stay, here comes the Fool with Apemantus.
Let’s ha’ some sport with ’em.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: Hang him! He’ll abuse us.

sp.speaker: ISIDORE’S MAN
sp.p: A plague upon him, dog!

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: How dost, Fool?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Dost dialogue with thy shadow?

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: I speak not to thee.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
No, ’tis to thyself. ( To the Fool.) Come
away.

sp.speaker: ISIDORE’S MAN
sp.p:
There’s the fool hangs
on your back already.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
No, thou stand’st single; thou ’rt not on
him yet.

sp.speaker: CAPHIS
sp.p: Where’s the fool now?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
He last asked the question. Poor rogues
and usurers’ men, bawds between gold and want.

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: What are we, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Asses.

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
That you ask me what you are, and do not
know yourselves.— Speak to ’em, Fool.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: How do you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p:
Gramercies, good Fool. How does your
mistress?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
She’s e’en setting on water to scald such chickens
as you are. Would we could see you at Corinth!

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Good. Gramercy.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Look you, here comes my master’s page.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Why, how now, captain? What do you in
this wise company?— How dost thou, Apemantus?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Would I had a rod in my mouth that I
might answer thee profitably.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Prithee, Apemantus, read me the superscription
of these letters. I know not which is which.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Canst not read?

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
There will little learning die, then, that
day thou art hanged. This is to Lord Timon, this to
Alcibiades. Go. Thou wast born a bastard, and
thou ’lt die a bawd.

sp.speaker: PAGE
sp.p:
Thou wast whelped a dog, and thou shalt famish
a dog’s death. Answer not. I am gone.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
E’en so thou outrunn’st grace.— Fool, I
will go with you to Lord Timon’s.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Will you leave me there?

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
If Timon stay at home.— You three serve
three usurers?

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: Ay. Would they served us!

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
So would I— as good a trick as ever hangman
served thief.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p: Are you three usurers’ men?

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: Ay, fool.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I think no usurer but has a fool to his servant.
My mistress is one, and I am her Fool. When men
come to borrow of your masters, they approach
sadly and go away merry, but they enter my master’s
house merrily and go away sadly. The reason
of this?

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: I could render one.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p:
Do it then, that we may account thee a
whoremaster and a knave, which notwithstanding,
thou shalt be no less esteemed.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: What is a whoremaster, fool?

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
A fool in good clothes, and something like thee.
’Tis a spirit; sometime ’t appears like a lord, sometime
like a lawyer, sometime like a philosopher,
with two stones more than ’s artificial one. He is
very often like a knight, and generally in all shapes
that man goes up and down in from fourscore to
thirteen, this spirit walks in.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S MAN
sp.p: Thou art not altogether a Fool.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
Nor thou altogether a wise man. As much foolery
as I have, so much wit thou lack’st.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: That answer might have become Apemantus.

sp.speaker: ALL THE MEN
sp.p: Aside, aside! Here comes Lord Timon.

sp.speaker: APEMANTUS
sp.p: Come with me, fool, come.

sp.speaker: FOOL
sp.p:
I do not always follow lover, elder brother, and
woman; sometime the philosopher.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Pray you, walk near. I’ll speak with you anon.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: You make me marvel wherefore ere this time
Had you not fully laid my state before me,
That I might so have rated my expense
As I had leave of means.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: You would not hear me.
At many leisures I proposed—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Go to.
Perchance some single vantages you took
When my indisposition put you back,
And that unaptness made your minister
Thus to excuse yourself.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: O, my good lord,
At many times I brought in my accounts,
Laid them before you. You would throw them off
And say you found them in mine honesty.
When for some trifling present you have bid me
Return so much, I have shook my head and wept—
Yea, ’gainst th’ authority of manners prayed you
To hold your hand more close. I did endure
Not seldom nor no slight checks when I have
Prompted you in the ebb of your estate
And your great flow of debts. My lovèd lord,
Though you hear now too late, yet now’s a time.
The greatest of your having lacks a half
To pay your present debts.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Let all my land be sold.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: ’Tis all engaged, some forfeited and gone,
And what remains will hardly stop the mouth
Of present dues. The future comes apace.
What shall defend the interim? And at length
How goes our reck’ning?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: To Lacedaemon did my land extend.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: O my good lord, the world is but a word.
Were it all yours to give it in a breath,
How quickly were it gone!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: You tell me true.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: If you suspect my husbandry of falsehood,
Call me before th’ exactest auditors,
And set me on the proof. So the gods bless me,
When all our offices have been oppressed
With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept
With drunken spilth of wine, when every room
Hath blazed with lights and brayed with minstrelsy,
I have retired me to a wasteful cock
And set mine eyes at flow.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Prithee, no more.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Heavens, have I said, the bounty of this lord!
How many prodigal bits have slaves and peasants
This night englutted. Who is not Timon’s?
What heart, head, sword, force, means, but is Lord Timon’s?
Great Timon, noble, worthy, royal Timon!
Ah, when the means are gone that buy this praise,
The breath is gone whereof this praise is made.
Feast-won, fast-lost. One cloud of winter showers,
These flies are couched.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Come, sermon me no further.
No villainous bounty yet hath passed my heart;
Unwisely, not ignobly, have I given.
Why dost thou weep? Canst thou the conscience lack
To think I shall lack friends? Secure thy heart.
If I would broach the vessels of my love
And try the argument of hearts by borrowing,
Men and men’s fortunes could I frankly use
As I can bid thee speak.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Assurance bless your thoughts!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: And in some sort these wants of mine are crowned,
That I account them blessings. For by these
Shall I try friends. You shall perceive how you
Mistake my fortunes. I am wealthy in my friends.—
Within there! Flaminius!— Servilius!

div.stage: Enter three Servants, Flaminius, Servilius, and another.

sp.speaker: SERVANTS
sp.p: My lord, my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: I will dispatch you severally.

You to Lord Lucius, ( to Flaminius) to Lord
Lucullus you— I hunted with his Honor today;

you to Sempronius. Commend
me to their loves, and I am proud, say, that my
occasions have found time to use ’em toward a
supply of money. Let the request be fifty talents.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.l: As you have said, my lord.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Lord Lucius and Lucullus? Humh!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Go you, sir, to the Senators,
Of whom, even to the state’s best health, I have
Deserved this hearing. Bid ’em send o’ th’ instant
A thousand talents to me.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: I have been bold—
For that I knew it the most general way—
To them to use your signet and your name,
But they do shake their heads, and I am here
No richer in return.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Is ’t true? Can ’t be?

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: They answer in a joint and corporate voice
That now they are at fall, want treasure, cannot
Do what they would, are sorry. You are honorable,
But yet they could have wished— they know not—
Something hath been amiss— a noble nature
May catch a wrench— would all were well— ’tis pity.
And so, intending other serious matters,
After distasteful looks and these hard fractions,
With certain half-caps and cold-moving nods
They froze me into silence.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: You gods, reward them!
Prithee, man, look cheerly. These old fellows
Have their ingratitude in them hereditary.
Their blood is caked, ’tis cold, it seldom flows;
’Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
And nature, as it grows again toward earth,
Is fashioned for the journey, dull and heavy.
Go to Ventidius. Prithee, be not sad.
Thou art true and honest— ingeniously I speak—
No blame belongs to thee. Ventidius lately
Buried his father, by whose death he’s stepped
Into a great estate. When he was poor,
Imprisoned, and in scarcity of friends,
I cleared him with five talents. Greet him from me.
Bid him suppose some good necessity
Touches his friend, which craves to be remembered
With those five talents. That had, give ’t these fellows
To whom ’tis instant due. Ne’er speak or think
That Timon’s fortunes ’mong his friends can sink.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: I would I could not think it.
That thought is bounty’s foe;
Being free itself, it thinks all others so.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Flaminius waiting to speak with Lucullus, from his master.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p:
I have told my lord of you. He is coming
down to you.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.p: I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Here’s my lord.

sp.speaker: LUCULLUS
sp.p:
One of Lord Timon’s men? A gift, I
warrant. Why, this hits right. I dreamt of a silver
basin and ewer tonight.— Flaminius, honest
Flaminius, you are very respectively welcome, sir.
( To Servant.) Fill me some wine.

And how does that honorable, complete, free-hearted
gentleman of Athens, thy very bountiful
good lord and master?

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.p: His health is well, sir.

sp.speaker: LUCULLUS
sp.p:
I am right glad that his health is well, sir.
And what hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty
Flaminius?

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.p:
Faith, nothing but an empty box, sir, which
in my lord’s behalf I come to entreat your Honor
to supply; who, having great and instant occasion
to use fifty talents, hath sent to your Lordship to
furnish him, nothing doubting your present assistance
therein.

sp.speaker: LUCULLUS
sp.p:
La, la, la, la. “ Nothing doubting” says he?
Alas, good lord! A noble gentleman ’tis, if he would
not keep so good a house. Many a time and often I
ha’ dined with him and told him on ’t, and come
again to supper to him of purpose to have him
spend less, and yet he would embrace no counsel,
take no warning by my coming. Every man has his
fault, and honesty is his. I ha’ told him on ’t, but I
could ne’er get him from ’t.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Please your Lordship, here is the wine.

sp.speaker: LUCULLUS
sp.p:
Flaminius, I have noted thee always wise.
Here’s to thee.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.p: Your Lordship speaks your pleasure.

sp.speaker: LUCULLUS
sp.p:
I have observed thee always for a towardly
prompt spirit— give thee thy due— and one that
knows what belongs to reason and canst use the
time well, if the time use thee well. Good parts in
thee.— Get you gone, sirrah.

Draw nearer, honest Flaminius. Thy lord’s a bountiful
gentleman, but thou art wise and thou
know’st well enough, although thou com’st to me,
that this is no time to lend money, especially upon
bare friendship, without security. Here’s three solidares
for thee. ( Gives him money.) Good boy,
wink at me, and say thou saw’st me not. Fare thee
well.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.l: Is ’t possible the world should so much differ,
And we alive that lived? Fly, damnèd baseness,
To him that worships thee!

div.stage: He throws the money back at Lucullus.

sp.speaker: LUCULLUS
sp.p:
Ha! Now I see thou art a fool and fit for thy
master.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.l: May these add to the number that may scald thee!
Let molten coin be thy damnation,
Thou disease of a friend and not himself!
Has friendship such a faint and milky heart
It turns in less than two nights? O you gods,
I feel my master’s passion. This slave
Unto his honor has my lord’s meat in him.
Why should it thrive and turn to nutriment
When he is turned to poison?
O, may diseases only work upon ’t,
And when he’s sick to death, let not that part of nature
Which my lord paid for be of any power
To expel sickness, but prolong his hour.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p:
Who, the Lord Timon? He is my very good
friend and an honorable gentleman.

sp.speaker: FIRST STRANGER
sp.p:
We know him for no less, though we
are but strangers to him. But I can tell you one
thing, my lord, and which I hear from common
rumors: now Lord Timon’s happy hours are done
and past, and his estate shrinks from him.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p:
Fie, no, do not believe it. He cannot want for
money.

sp.speaker: SECOND STRANGER
sp.p:
But believe you this, my lord, that
not long ago one of his men was with the Lord
Lucullus to borrow fifty talents, nay, urged
extremely for ’t, and showed what necessity
belonged to ’t, and yet was denied.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: SECOND STRANGER
sp.p: I tell you, denied, my lord.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p:
What a strange case was that! Now, before the
gods, I am ashamed on ’t. Denied that honorable
man? There was very little honor showed in ’t. For
my own part, I must needs confess I have received
some small kindnesses from him, as money, plate,
jewels, and suchlike trifles, nothing comparing to
his; yet had he mistook him and sent to me, I
should ne’er have denied his occasion fifty talents.

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.p:
See, by good hap, yonder’s my lord.
I have sweat to see his Honor. To Lucius. My
honored lord.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p:
Servilius. You are kindly met, sir. Fare thee
well. Commend me to thy honorable virtuous lord,
my very exquisite friend.

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.p:
May it please your Honor, my lord hath
sent—

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p:
Ha! What has he sent? I am so much endeared
to that lord; he’s ever sending. How shall I thank
him, think’st thou? And what has he sent now?

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.p:
Has only sent his present occasion now, my
lord, requesting your Lordship to supply his
instant use with fifty talents.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.l: I know his Lordship is but merry with me.
He cannot want fifty-five hundred talents.

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.l: But in the meantime he wants less, my lord.
If his occasion were not virtuous,
I should not urge it half so faithfully.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.l: Dost thou speak seriously, Servilius?

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.l: Upon my soul, ’tis true, sir.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p:
What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish
myself against such a good time, when I might ha’
shown myself honorable! How unluckily it happened
that I should purchase the day before for a
little part, and undo a great deal of honor! Servilius,
now before the gods, I am not able to do— the
more beast, I say!— I was sending to use Lord
Timon myself, these gentlemen can witness; but I
would not for the wealth of Athens I had done ’t
now. Commend me bountifully to his good Lordship,
and I hope his Honor will conceive the fairest
of me, because I have no power to be kind. And tell
him this from me: I count it one of my greatest
afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an honorable
gentleman. Good Servilius, will you
befriend me so far as to use mine own words to
him?

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.l: Yes, sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS
sp.p: I’ll look you out a good turn, Servilius.
sp.l: True, as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed,
And he that’s once denied will hardly speed.

sp.speaker: FIRST STRANGER
sp.l: Do you observe this, Hostilius?

sp.speaker: SECOND STRANGER
sp.l: Ay, too well.

sp.speaker: FIRST STRANGER
sp.l: Why, this is the world’s soul, and just of the same piece
Is every flatterer’s sport. Who can call him his friend
That dips in the same dish? For, in my knowing,
Timon has been this lord’s father
And kept his credit with his purse,
Supported his estate, nay, Timon’s money
Has paid his men their wages. He ne’er drinks
But Timon’s silver treads upon his lip.
And yet— O, see the monstrousness of man
When he looks out in an ungrateful shape!—
He does deny him, in respect of his,
What charitable men afford to beggars.

sp.speaker: THIRD STRANGER
sp.l: Religion groans at it.

sp.speaker: FIRST STRANGER
sp.l: For mine own part,
I never tasted Timon in my life,
Nor came any of his bounties over me
To mark me for his friend. Yet I protest,
For his right noble mind, illustrious virtue,
And honorable carriage,
Had his necessity made use of me,
I would have put my wealth into donation,
And the best half should have returned to him,
So much I love his heart. But I perceive
Men must learn now with pity to dispense,
For policy sits above conscience.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter a Third Servant of Timon’s with Sempronius, another of Timon’s friends.

sp.speaker: SEMPRONIUS
sp.l: Must he needs trouble me in ’t? Hum! ’Bove all others?
He might have tried Lord Lucius or Lucullus;
And now Ventidius is wealthy too,
Whom he redeemed from prison. All these
Owes their estates unto him.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: My lord,
They have all been touched and found base metal,
For they have all denied him.

sp.speaker: SEMPRONIUS
sp.l: How? Have they denied him?
Has Ventidius and Lucullus denied him,
And does he send to me? Three? Humh!
It shows but little love or judgment in him.
Must I be his last refuge? His friends, like physicians,
Thrive, give him over. Must I take th’ cure upon me?
Has much disgraced me in ’t. I’m angry at him
That might have known my place. I see no sense for ’t
But his occasions might have wooed me first;
For, in my conscience, I was the first man
That e’er received gift from him.
And does he think so backwardly of me now
That I’ll requite it last? No.
So it may prove an argument of laughter
To th’ rest, and I ’mongst lords be thought a fool.
I’d rather than the worth of thrice the sum
Had sent to me first, but for my mind’s sake;
I’d such a courage to do him good. But now return,
And with their faint reply this answer join:
Who bates mine honor shall not know my coin.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p:
Excellent! Your Lordship’s a goodly villain.
The devil knew not what he did when he made
man politic. He crossed himself by ’t, and I cannot
think but, in the end, the villainies of man will set
him clear. How fairly this lord strives to appear
foul! Takes virtuous copies to be wicked, like those
that under hot ardent zeal would set whole realms
on fire.
sp.l: Of such a nature is his politic love.
This was my lord’s best hope. Now all are fled,
Save only the gods. Now his friends are dead,
Doors that were ne’er acquainted with their wards
Many a bounteous year must be employed
Now to guard sure their master.
And this is all a liberal course allows:
Who cannot keep his wealth must keep his house.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Varro’s two Men, meeting Titus and others, all being Men of Timon’s creditors to wait for his coming out. Then enter Lucius’ Man and Hortensius.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S FIRST MAN
sp.l: Well met. Good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: The like to you, kind Varro.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIUS
sp.l: Lucius!
What, do we meet together?

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Ay, and I think
One business does command us all,
For mine is money.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: So is theirs and ours.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: And, sir, Philotus’ too.

sp.speaker: PHILOTUS
sp.l: Good day at once.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Welcome, good brother.
What do you think the hour?

sp.speaker: PHILOTUS
sp.l: Laboring for nine.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: So much?

sp.speaker: PHILOTUS
sp.l: Is not my lord seen yet?

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: PHILOTUS
sp.l: I wonder on ’t. He was wont to shine at seven.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Ay, but the days are waxed shorter with him.
You must consider that a prodigal course
Is like the sun’s,
But not, like his, recoverable. I fear
’Tis deepest winter in Lord Timon’s purse:
That is, one may reach deep enough and yet
Find little.

sp.speaker: PHILOTUS
sp.l: I am of your fear for that.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: I’ll show you how t’ observe a strange event.
Your lord sends now for money?

sp.speaker: HORTENSIUS
sp.l: Most true, he does.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: And he wears jewels now of Timon’s gift,
For which I wait for money.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIUS
sp.l: It is against my heart.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Mark how strange it shows:
Timon in this should pay more than he owes,
And e’en as if your lord should wear rich jewels
And send for money for ’em.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIUS
sp.l: I’m weary of this charge, the gods can witness.
I know my lord hath spent of Timon’s wealth,
And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S FIRST MAN
sp.l: Yes, mine’s three thousand crowns. What’s yours?

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Five thousand mine.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S FIRST MAN
sp.l: ’Tis much deep, and it should seem by th’ sum
Your master’s confidence was above mine,
Else surely his had equaled.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: One of Lord Timon’s men.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.p:
Flaminius? Sir, a word. Pray, is my lord
ready to come forth?

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.p: No, indeed he is not.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.p: We attend his Lordship. Pray, signify so much.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.p:
I need not tell him that. He knows you are
too diligent.

div.stage: Enter Flavius, the Steward in a cloak, muffled.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Ha! Is not that his steward muffled so?
He goes away in a cloud. Call him, call him.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: VARRO’S SECOND MAN
sp.l: By your leave, sir.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: What do you ask of me, my friend?

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: We wait for certain money here, sir.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Ay,
If money were as certain as your waiting,
’Twere sure enough.
Why then preferred you not your sums and bills
When your false masters eat of my lord’s meat?
Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts
And take down th’ int’rest into their glutt’nous maws.
You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up.
Let me pass quietly.
Believe ’t, my lord and I have made an end.
I have no more to reckon, he to spend.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Ay, but this answer will not serve.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: If ’twill not serve, ’tis not so base as you,
For you serve knaves.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S FIRST MAN
sp.p:
How? What does his cashiered
Worship mutter?

sp.speaker: VARRO’S SECOND MAN
sp.p:
No matter what. He’s poor, and
that’s revenge enough. Who can speak broader
than he that has no house to put his head in? Such
may rail against great buildings.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.p:
O, here’s Servilius. Now we shall know some
answer.

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.p:
If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair
some other hour, I should derive much from ’t. For
take ’t of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to discontent.
His comfortable temper has forsook him.
He’s much out of health and keeps his chamber.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Many do keep their chambers are not sick;
And if it be so far beyond his health,
Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts
And make a clear way to the gods.

sp.speaker: SERVILIUS
sp.l: Good gods!

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

sp.speaker: FLAMINIUS
sp.l: Servilius, help! My lord, my lord!

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: What, are my doors opposed against my passage?
Have I been ever free, and must my house
Be my retentive enemy, my jail?
The place which I have feasted, does it now,
Like all mankind, show me an iron heart?

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.p: Put in now, Titus.

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: My lord, here is my bill.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.p: Here’s mine.

sp.speaker: HORTENSIUS
sp.p: And mine, my lord.

sp.speaker: VARRO’S SECOND MAN
sp.p: And ours, my lord.

sp.speaker: PHILOTUS
sp.p: All our bills.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Knock me down with ’em! Cleave me to the girdle.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Alas, my lord—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Cut my heart in sums!

sp.speaker: TITUS
sp.l: Mine, fifty talents.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Tell out my blood.

sp.speaker: LUCIUS’ MAN
sp.l: Five thousand crowns, my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Five thousand drops pays that.— What yours?— And yours?

sp.speaker: VARRO’S FIRST MAN
sp.l: My lord—

sp.speaker: VARRO’S SECOND MAN
sp.l: My lord—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!

sp.speaker: HORTENSIUS
sp.p:
Faith, I perceive our masters may throw
their caps at their money. These debts may well be
called desperate ones, for a madman owes ’em.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: They have e’en put my breath from me, the slaves!
Creditors? Devils!

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: My dear lord—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: What if it should be so?

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: My lord—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I’ll have it so.— My steward!

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again,
Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius, all.
I’ll once more feast the rascals.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: O my lord,
You only speak from your distracted soul.
There’s not so much left to furnish out
A moderate table.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Be it not in thy care. Go,
I charge thee, invite them all. Let in the tide
Of knaves once more. My cook and I’ll provide.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter three Senators at one door, Alcibiades meeting them, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: My lord, you have my voice to ’t. The fault’s
Bloody. ’Tis necessary he should die.
Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.

sp.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
sp.l: Most true. The law shall bruise ’em.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Honor, health, and compassion to the Senate!

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: Now, captain?

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: I am an humble suitor to your virtues,
For pity is the virtue of the law,
And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
It pleases time and fortune to lie heavy
Upon a friend of mine, who in hot blood
Hath stepped into the law, which is past depth
To those that without heed do plunge into ’t.
He is a man— setting his fate aside—
Of comely virtues.
Nor did he soil the fact with cowardice—
An honor in him which buys out his fault—
But with a noble fury and fair spirit,
Seeing his reputation touched to death,
He did oppose his foe;
And with such sober and unnoted passion
He did behave his anger, ere ’twas spent,
As if he had but proved an argument.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: You undergo too strict a paradox,
Striving to make an ugly deed look fair.
Your words have took such pains as if they labored
To bring manslaughter into form and set quarreling
Upon the head of valor— which indeed
Is valor misbegot, and came into the world
When sects and factions were newly born.
He’s truly valiant that can wisely suffer
The worst that man can breathe
And make his wrongs his outsides,
To wear them like his raiment, carelessly,
And ne’er prefer his injuries to his heart
To bring it into danger.
If wrongs be evils and enforce us kill,
What folly ’tis to hazard life for ill!

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: My lord—

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: You cannot make gross sins look clear.
To revenge is no valor, but to bear.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: My lords, then, under favor, pardon me
If I speak like a captain.
Why do fond men expose themselves to battle
And not endure all threats? Sleep upon ’t,
And let the foes quietly cut their throats
Without repugnancy? If there be
Such valor in the bearing, what make we
Abroad? Why, then, women are more valiant
That stay at home, if bearing carry it,
And the ass more captain than the lion, the felon
Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,
If wisdom be in suffering. O my lords,
As you are great, be pitifully good.
Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?
To kill, I grant, is sin’s extremest gust,
But in defense, by mercy, ’tis most just.
To be in anger is impiety,
But who is man that is not angry?
Weigh but the crime with this.

sp.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
sp.l: You breathe in vain.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: In vain? His service done
At Lacedaemon and Byzantium
Were a sufficient briber for his life.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: What’s that?

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Why, I say, my lords, has done fair service
And slain in fight many of your enemies.
How full of valor did he bear himself
In the last conflict, and made plenteous wounds!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
sp.l: He has made too much plenty with ’em.
He’s a sworn rioter. He has a sin
That often drowns him and takes his valor prisoner.
If there were no foes, that were enough
To overcome him. In that beastly fury,
He has been known to commit outrages
And cherish factions. ’Tis inferred to us
His days are foul and his drink dangerous.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: He dies.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Hard fate! He might have died in war.
My lords, if not for any parts in him—
Though his right arm might purchase his own time
And be in debt to none— yet, more to move you,
Take my deserts to his and join ’em both.
And, for I know your reverend ages love
Security, I’ll pawn my victories, all
My honor, to you, upon his good returns.
If by this crime he owes the law his life,
Why, let the war receive ’t in valiant gore,
For law is strict, and war is nothing more.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: We are for law. He dies. Urge it no more,
On height of our displeasure. Friend or brother,
He forfeits his own blood that spills another.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Must it be so? It must not be.
My lords, I do beseech you, know me.

sp.speaker: SECOND SENATOR
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Call me to your remembrances.

sp.speaker: THIRD SENATOR
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: I cannot think but your age has forgot me.
It could not else be I should prove so base
To sue and be denied such common grace.
My wounds ache at you.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: Do you dare our anger?
’Tis in few words, but spacious in effect:
We banish thee forever.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Banish me?
Banish your dotage, banish usury,
That makes the Senate ugly!

sp.speaker: FIRST SENATOR
sp.l: If after two days’ shine Athens contain thee,
Attend our weightier judgment.
And, not to swell our spirit,
He shall be executed presently.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: Now the gods keep you old enough that you may live
Only in bone, that none may look on you!—
I’m worse than mad. I have kept back their foes
While they have told their money and let out
Their coin upon large interest, I myself
Rich only in large hurts. All those for this?
Is this the balsam that the usuring Senate
Pours into captains’ wounds? Banishment.
It comes not ill. I hate not to be banished.
It is a cause worthy my spleen and fury,
That I may strike at Athens. I’ll cheer up
My discontented troops and lay for hearts.
’Tis honor with most lands to be at odds.
Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.

div.head: Scene 6
div.stage: Music. Enter divers Friends at several doors.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: The good time of day to you, sir.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
I also wish it to you. I think this honorable
lord did but try us this other day.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p:
Upon that were my thoughts tiring when
we encountered. I hope it is not so low with him as
he made it seem in the trial of his several friends.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
It should not be, by the persuasion of
his new feasting.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p:
I should think so. He hath sent me an
earnest inviting, which many my near occasions
did urge me to put off; but he hath conjured me
beyond them, and I must needs appear.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
In like manner was I in debt to my
importunate business, but he would not hear my
excuse. I am sorry, when he sent to borrow of me,
that my provision was out.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p:
I am sick of that grief too, as I understand
how all things go.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
Every man here’s so. What would he
have borrowed of you?

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: A thousand pieces.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: A thousand pieces!

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: What of you?

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: He sent to me, sir—
Here he comes.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
With all my heart, gentlemen both! And how
fare you?

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p:
Ever at the best, hearing well of your
Lordship.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
The swallow follows not summer
more willing than we your Lordship.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
Nor more willingly leaves winter, such
summer birds are men.— Gentlemen, our dinner
will not recompense this long stay. Feast your ears
with the music awhile, if they will fare so harshly
o’ th’ trumpets’ sound. We shall to ’t presently.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p:
I hope it remains not unkindly with your
Lordship that I returned you an empty messenger.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: O, sir, let it not trouble you.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: My noble lord—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Ah, my good friend, what cheer?

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
My most honorable lord, I am e’en
sick of shame that when your Lordship this other
day sent to me, I was so unfortunate a beggar.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Think not on ’t, sir.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: If you had sent but two hours before—

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: Let it not cumber your better remembrance.
Come, bring in all together.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: All covered dishes!

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: Royal cheer, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p:
Doubt not that, if money and the season
can yield it.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: How do you? What’s the news?

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p: Alcibiades is banished. Hear you of it?

sp.speaker: FIRST AND SECOND FRIENDS
sp.p: Alcibiades banished?

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p: ’Tis so. Be sure of it.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: How? How?

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: I pray you, upon what?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p: My worthy friends, will you draw near?

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p:
I’ll tell you more anon. Here’s a noble
feast toward.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: This is the old man still.

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p: Will ’t hold? Will ’t hold?

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: It does, but time will— and so—

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p: I do conceive.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.p:
Each man to his stool, with that spur as he
would to the lip of his mistress. Your diet shall
be in all places alike. Make not a city feast of it, to let
the meat cool ere we can agree upon the first place.
Sit, sit. ( They sit.) The gods require our thanks:
You great benefactors, sprinkle our society with
thankfulness. For your own gifts make yourselves
praised, but reserve still to give, lest your deities be
despised. Lend to each man enough, that one need
not lend to another; for, were your godheads to
borrow of men, men would forsake the gods. Make
the meat be beloved more than the man that gives
it. Let no assembly of twenty be without a score of
villains. If there sit twelve women at the table, let a
dozen of them be as they are. The rest of your fees,
O gods, the Senators of Athens, together with the
common tag of people, what is amiss in them,
you gods, make suitable for destruction. For these
my present friends, as they are to me nothing, so
in nothing bless them, and to nothing are they
welcome.
sp.l: Uncover, dogs, and lap.

div.stage: The dishes are uncovered. They contain only water and stones.

sp.speaker: SOME SPEAK
sp.l: What does his Lordship mean?

sp.speaker: SOME OTHER
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: May you a better feast never behold,
You knot of mouth-friends! Smoke and lukewarm water
Is your perfection. This is Timon’s last,
Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,
Washes it off and sprinkles in your faces
Your reeking villainy.
sp.stage: ( He throws water in their faces.)
sp.l: Live loathed and long,
Most smiling, smooth, detested parasites,
Courteous destroyers, affable wolves, meek bears,
You fools of fortune, trencher-friends, time’s flies,
Cap-and-knee slaves, vapors, and minute-jacks.
Of man and beast the infinite malady
Crust you quite o’er! ( They stand.) What, dost thou go?
Soft! Take thy physic first— thou too— and thou.—
Stay. I will lend thee money, borrow none.
sp.stage: He attacks them and forces them out.
sp.l: What? All in motion? Henceforth be no feast
Whereat a villain’s not a welcome guest.
Burn, house! Sink, Athens! Henceforth hated be
Of Timon man and all humanity!

div.stage: Enter Timon’s Friends, the Senators, with other Lords.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: How now, my lords?

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p:
Know you the quality of Lord Timon’s
fury?

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p: Push! Did you see my cap?

sp.speaker: FOURTH FRIEND
sp.p: I have lost my gown.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p:
He’s but a mad lord, and naught but
humors sways him. He gave me a jewel th’ other
day, and now he has beat it out of my hat. Did you
see my jewel?

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.p: Did you see my cap?

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.p: Here ’tis.

sp.speaker: FOURTH FRIEND
sp.p: Here lies my gown.

sp.speaker: FIRST FRIEND
sp.p: Let’s make no stay.

sp.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
sp.l: Lord Timon’s mad.

sp.speaker: THIRD FRIEND
sp.l: I feel ’t upon my bones.

sp.speaker: FOURTH FRIEND
sp.l: One day he gives us diamonds, next day stones.

div.stage: The Senators and the others exit.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: Let me look back upon thee. O thou wall
That girdles in those wolves, dive in the earth
And fence not Athens! Matrons, turn incontinent!
Obedience fail in children! Slaves and fools,
Pluck the grave wrinkled Senate from the bench
And minister in their steads! To general filths
Convert o’ th’ instant, green virginity!
Do ’t in your parents’ eyes! Bankrupts, hold fast!
Rather than render back, out with your knives
And cut your trusters’ throats! Bound servants, steal!
Large-handed robbers your grave masters are,
And pill by law. Maid, to thy master’s bed!
Thy mistress is o’ th’ brothel. Son of sixteen,
Pluck the lined crutch from thy old limping sire;
With it beat out his brains! Piety and fear,
Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth,
Domestic awe, night rest, and neighborhood,
Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades,
Degrees, observances, customs, and laws,
Decline to your confounding contraries,
And yet confusion live! Plagues incident to men,
Your potent and infectious fevers heap
On Athens, ripe for stroke! Thou cold sciatica,
Cripple our senators, that their limbs may halt
As lamely as their manners! Lust and liberty,
Creep in the minds and marrows of our youth,
That ’gainst the stream of virtue they may strive
And drown themselves in riot! Itches, blains,
Sow all th’ Athenian bosoms, and their crop
Be general leprosy! Breath infect breath,
That their society, as their friendship, may
Be merely poison! Nothing I’ll bear from thee
But nakedness, thou detestable town!
Take thou that too, with multiplying bans!
Timon will to the woods, where he shall find
Th’ unkindest beast more kinder than mankind.
The gods confound— hear me, you good gods all!—
Th’ Athenians both within and out that wall,
And grant, as Timon grows, his hate may grow
To the whole race of mankind, high and low!
Amen.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Steward Flavius with two or three Servants.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT
sp.l: Hear you, Master Steward, where’s our master?
Are we undone, cast off, nothing remaining?

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Alack, my fellows, what should I say to you?
Let me be recorded by the righteous gods,
I am as poor as you.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT
sp.l: Such a house broke?
So noble a master fall’n, all gone, and not
One friend to take his fortune by the arm
And go along with him?

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT
sp.l: As we do turn our backs
From our companion thrown into his grave,
So his familiars to his buried fortunes
Slink all away, leave their false vows with him,
Like empty purses picked; and his poor self,
A dedicated beggar to the air,
With his disease of all-shunned poverty,
Walks, like contempt, alone.
More of our fellows.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: All broken implements of a ruined house.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVANT
sp.l: Yet do our hearts wear Timon’s livery.
That see I by our faces. We are fellows still,
Serving alike in sorrow. Leaked is our bark,
And we, poor mates, stand on the dying deck,
Hearing the surges threat. We must all part
Into this sea of air.

sp.speaker: FLAVIUS
sp.l: Good fellows all,
The latest of my wealth I’ll share amongst you.
Wherever we shall meet, for Timon’s sake
Let’s yet be fellows. Let’s shake our heads and say,
As ’twere a knell unto our master’s fortunes,
“ We have seen better days.”
Let each take some.
Nay, put out all your hands. Not one word more.
Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor.
sp.stage: The Servants embrace and part several ways.
sp.l: O, the fierce wretchedness that glory brings us!
Who would not wish to be from wealth exempt,
Since riches point to misery and contempt?
Who would be so mocked with glory, or to live
But in a dream of friendship,
To have his pomp and all what state compounds
But only painted, like his varnished friends?
Poor honest lord, brought low by his own heart,
Undone by goodness! Strange unusual blood
When man’s worst sin is he does too much good!
Who then dares to be half so kind again?
For bounty, that makes gods, do still mar men.
My dearest lord, blest to be most accursed,
Rich only to be wretched, thy great fortunes
Are made thy chief afflictions. Alas, kind lord!
He’s flung in rage from this ingrateful seat
Of monstrous friends,
Nor has he with him to supply his life,
Or that which can command it.
I’ll follow and inquire him out.
I’ll ever serve his mind with my best will.
Whilst I have gold, I’ll be his steward still.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Timon in the woods, with a spade.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: O blessèd breeding sun, draw from the Earth
Rotten humidity! Below thy sister’s orb
Infect the air! Twinned brothers of one womb,
Whose procreation, residence, and birth
Scarce is dividant, touch them with several fortunes,
The greater scorns the lesser. Not nature,
To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortune
But by contempt of nature.
Raise me this beggar, and deny ’t that lord;
The Senators shall bear contempt hereditary,
The beggar native honor.
It is the pasture lards the brother’s sides,
The want that makes him lean. Who dares, who dares
In purity of manhood stand upright
And say “ This man’s a flatterer”? If one be,
So are they all, for every grise of fortune
Is smoothed by that below. The learnèd pate
Ducks to the golden fool. All’s obliquy.
There’s nothing level in our cursèd natures
But direct villainy. Therefore be abhorred
All feasts, societies, and throngs of men.
His semblable, yea, himself, Timon disdains.
Destruction fang mankind! Earth, yield me roots!
Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate
With thy most operant poison!
What is here?
Gold? Yellow, glittering, precious gold?
No, gods, I am no idle votarist.
Roots, you clear heavens! Thus much of this will make
Black white, foul fair, wrong right,
Base noble, old young, coward valiant.
Ha, you gods! Why this? What this, you gods? Why, this
Will lug your priests and servants from your sides,
Pluck stout men’s pillows from below their heads.
This yellow slave
Will knit and break religions, bless th’ accursed,
Make the hoar leprosy adored, place thieves
And give them title, knee, and approbation
With senators on the bench. This is it
That makes the wappened widow wed again;
She whom the spital house and ulcerous sores
Would cast the gorge at, this embalms and spices
To th’ April day again. Come, damnèd earth,
Thou common whore of mankind, that puts odds
Among the rout of nations, I will make thee
Do thy right nature. ( March afar off.) Ha? A drum? Thou ’rt quick,
But yet I’ll bury thee. Thou ’lt go, strong thief,
When gouty keepers of thee cannot stand.
Nay, stay thou out for earnest.

div.stage: He buries the gold, keeping some out.
Enter Alcibiades, with Drum and Fife, in warlike manner, and Phrynia and Timandra.

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: What art thou there? Speak.

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: A beast, as thou art. The canker gnaw thy heart
For showing me again the eyes of man!

sp.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sp.l: What is thy name? Is man so hateful to thee
That art thyself a man?

sp.speaker: TIMON
sp.l: I am Misanthropos and hate mankind.
For thy part, I do wish thou wert a dog,
That I might love thee something.
